message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with acute onset severe abdominal pain and vomiting, irregularly irregular heart rhythm, and a history of hypertension and recent cessation of hydrochlorothiazide. Laboratory studies show elevated lactate, leukocytosis, and normal procoagulant profile. CT angiography confirms the diagnosis of mesenteric ischemia, likely caused by embolus from cardiac arrhythmia. The most appropriate definitive management is balloon angioplasty and stenting to restore blood flow to the affected areas of the intestine. Anticoagulation with heparin may be considered as part of adjunctive treatment, but it alone does not address the underlying vascular obstruction. Colonoscopy and MR angiography are not indicated for the acute management of mesenteric ischemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has symptoms and lab results suggestive of acute mesenteric ischemia, and the CT angiography confirmed the diagnosis. Balloon angioplasty and stenting is the most appropriate definitive management for this condition. Anticoagulation with heparin is indicated in some cases but not definitive management. Colonoscopy and MR angiography are not appropriate for this immediate situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, physical examination findings, and laboratory studies suggest mesenteric ischemia. The most appropriate definitive management is balloon angioplasty and stenting to restore blood flow to the affected area. Anticoagulation with heparin may be used as a temporary measure before definitive management, but it is not the most appropriate definitive management. Colonoscopy and MR angiography are not appropriate for the diagnosis and management of mesenteric ischemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a diagnosis of mesenteric ischemia, and CT angiography confirms it. The treatment of choice for acute mesenteric ischemia caused by arterial occlusion is balloon angioplasty with stenting to restore blood flow to the affected segment of intestine. Anticoagulation therapy is not sufficient for treating acute mesenteric ischemia. Colonoscopy and MR angiography are not indicated in this situation.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with symptoms consistent with acute mesenteric ischemia. CT angiography has confirmed the diagnosis, and the most appropriate definitive management is balloon angioplasty and stenting to restore blood flow to the affected mesenteric vessels. Anticoagulation with heparin is indicated as part of the management but is not the definitive treatment. Colonoscopy and MR angiography may be helpful in the diagnosis but are not definitive treatments.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The sudden onset of severe abdominal pain with vomiting and loose bowel movement suggests acute mesenteric ischemia, which was confirmed by CT angiography. Balloon angioplasty and stenting are the most appropriate definitive management options for this condition. Anticoagulation with heparin is used for the initial treatment of mesenteric ischemia but is not the definitive management. Colonoscopy and MR angiography are not appropriate for acute mesenteric ischemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest acute mesenteric ischemia, which is confirmed by CT angiography. The most appropriate definitive management is balloon angioplasty and stenting to restore blood flow to the affected branch of the mesenteric artery. Anticoagulation with heparin may be used as adjunct therapy, but it is not the most appropriate definitive management. Colonoscopy and MR angiography are not appropriate for the management of acute mesenteric ischemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms and laboratory results suggest mesenteric ischemia, and CT angiography confirms the diagnosis. Balloon angioplasty and stenting is the most appropriate definitive management to restore blood flow to the affected area. Anticoagulation with heparin may be used as an adjunctive treatment but is not the definitive management. Colonoscopy and MR angiography are not recommended for the treatment of mesenteric ischemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and CT angiography confirm the diagnosis of mesenteric ischemia. The most appropriate definitive management is balloon angioplasty and stenting to restore blood flow to the affected area. Anticoagulation with heparin may be used in conjunction with balloon angioplasty, but it alone will not provide definitive management. Colonoscopy and MR angiography are not appropriate management for mesenteric ischemia.

The definitive management for mesenteric ischemia is balloon angioplasty and stenting to restore blood flow to the affected area. Anticoagulation with heparin may be used in conjunction with this treatment. Colonoscopy and MR angiography are not appropriate for the management of acute mesenteric ischemia.
